Title: Missouri Learning Standards > English Language Arts > Grade 2

Subs.Label: Develop and apply skills to the reading process.
Comprehension
Develop and demonstrate reading skills in response to text by using text features to make and confirm predictions, explain why not confirmed.
Develop and demonstrate reading skills in response to text by asking and responding to relevant questions.
Develop and demonstrate reading skills in response to text by seeking clarification and using information/facts and details about texts and supporting answers with evidence from text.
Develop and demonstrate reading skills in response to text by retelling a storyâ€™s beginning, middle, and end and determining its central message, lesson, or moral.
Develop and demonstrate reading skills in response to text by monitoring comprehension and making corrections and adjustments when understanding breaks down.
Vocabulary
Develop an understanding of vocabulary by using prefixes, root words, and suffixes to determine the meaning of words.
Develop an understanding of vocabulary by using knowledge of the meaning of individual words to determine the meaning of compound words.
Develop an understanding of vocabulary by using context to determine the meaning of a new word or multiple-meaning word in text.
Develop an understanding of vocabulary by using antonyms and synonyms.
Develop an understanding of vocabulary by locating words in a dictionary or glossary to determine or clarify the meaning of words or phrases.
Develop an understanding of vocabulary by distinguishing meaning among closely related verbs and adjectives.
Develop an understanding of vocabulary by recognizing that some words have literal and non-literal meanings.
Develop an understanding of vocabulary by using conversational, general academic, and domain-specific words and phrases.
Making Connections
Determine the relevant connections between text to text (text ideas, including similarities and differences regarding information and relationships in fiction and nonfiction).
Determine the relevant connections between text to world (text ideas regarding experiences in the world).
Independent Text
Read independently for multiple purposes over sustained periods of time by reading text that is developmentally appropriate.
Read independently for multiple purposes over sustained periods of time by reading text that is developmentally appropriate.
Develop and apply skills and strategies to comprehend, analyze, and evaluate fiction, poetry, and drama from a variety of cultures and times.
Fiction
Read, infer, analyze, and draw conclusions to describe the setting, problems, solutions, sequence of events (plot), and big idea or moral lesson.
Read, infer, analyze, and draw conclusions to describe the main characters in works of fiction, including their traits, motivations, and feelings.
Read, infer, analyze, and draw conclusions to compare and contrast different versions of the same story with respect to their characters, settings, and sequence of events.
Read, infer, analyze, and draw conclusions to describe cause-and-effect relationships.
Read, infer, analyze, and draw conclusions to explain how the story changes based on who is telling the story.
Read, infer, analyze, and draw conclusions to compare and contrast the differences in points of view of characters and how stories are narrated.
Poetry
Read, infer, and draw conclusions to describe how rhythm, rhyme, and repetition create imagery in poetry.
Read, infer, and draw conclusions to use onomatopoeia.
Drama
Read, infer, and draw conclusions to identify characters, setting, acts, and scenes in plays.
Read, infer, and draw conclusions to identify the elements of dialogue and use them in informal plays.

Develop and apply skills and strategies to comprehend, analyze, and evaluate nonfiction (e.g., narrative, information/explanatory, opinion, persuasive, argumentative) from a variety of cultures and times.
Text Features
Read, infer, and draw conclusions to identify the main idea of sections of text and distinguish it from the topic.
Read, infer, and draw conclusions to demonstrate understanding by locating facts to answer and/or ask questions.
Read, infer, and draw conclusions to use text features to locate specific information.
Read, infer, and draw conclusions to explain common graphic features to assist in the interpretation of text.
Read, infer, and draw conclusions to follow written multi-step directions.
Read, infer, and draw conclusions to describe connections between and state the order of the events or ideas.
Literary Techniques
Read, infer, and draw conclusions to explain why a text is fiction or nonfiction.
Read, infer, and draw conclusions to ask and answer questions to clarify meaning.
Read, infer, and draw conclusions to explain examples of sensory details.
Text Structures
Read, infer, and draw conclusions to explain main ideas and supporting details.
Read, infer, and draw conclusions to describe the  connection between events and retell the sequence of events.
Read, infer, and draw conclusions to describe the connection between and identify problems and solutions.
Read, infer, and draw conclusions to identify the authorâ€™s purpose.
Read, infer, and draw conclusions to compare and contrast the most important points presented by text on the same topic.
Comprehend and analyze words, images, graphics, and sounds in various media and digital forms to impact meaning.
Digital and Media Literacy
Read to develop an understanding of media and its components by explaining purposes of media.
Read to develop an understanding of media and its components by describing techniques used to create media messages.
Read to develop an understanding of media and its components by identifying various written conventions for using digital media.
Understand how English is written and read.
Print Awareness
Develop print awareness in the reading process by understanding that sentences are organized into paragraphs to convey meaning.
Understand how English is written and read.
Phonics

Develop phonics in the reading process by decoding multisyllabic words in context by applying common letter-sound correspondences including single letters, consonant blends, consonant and vowel digraphs, and vowel diphthongs.
Develop phonics in the reading process by distinguishing long and short vowels when reading regularly spelled one-syllable words.
Develop phonics in the reading process by decoding regularly spelled two-syllable words with long vowels.
Develop phonics in the reading process by decoding words with vowel diphthongs.
Develop phonics in the reading process by decoding words with vowel digraphs.
Develop phonics in the reading process by reading words with common prefixes and suffixes.
Develop phonics in the reading process by using contractions.
Develop phonics in the reading process by using common syllable patterns to decode words including r-controlled vowels.
Develop phonics in the reading process by reading irregularly spelled high-frequency words.
Develop phonics in the reading process by demonstrating decoding skills when reading new words in a text.
Understand how English is written and read.
Fluency

Read appropriate texts with fluency (rate, accuracy, expression, appropriate phrasing), with purpose, and for comprehension use context to confirm or self-correct word recognition and understanding, rereading as necessary.
Apply a writing process to develop a text for audience and purpose.
Prewriting
Follow a writing process to plan a first draft by brainstorming and recording key ideas using a graphic organizer.
Draft
Appropriate to genre type, develop a draft from prewriting by sequencing ideas into clear and coherent sentences.
Appropriate to genre type, develop a draft from prewriting by generating paragraphs with one main idea.
Appropriate to genre type, develop a draft from prewriting by creating evidence of a beginning, middle, and end.
Appropriate to genre type, develop a draft from prewriting by addressing an appropriate audience.
Revise/Edit
Reread, revise, and edit drafts with assistance from adults/peers to strengthen writing as needed by revising main idea, details, word choice, sentence construction, event order, audience, voice.
Reread, revise, and edit drafts with assistance from adults/peers to edit for language conventions.
Produce/Publish & Share Writing
With assistance from adults/peers use a variety of conventional/digital tools to produce and publish writing.
With assistance from adults/peers introduce keyboarding skills.
Compose well-developed writing texts for audience and purpose.
Opinion/Argumentative
Write opinion texts that introduce a topic or text being studied, using complete sentences.
Write opinion texts that state an opinion about the topic or text and provide reasons for the opinion.
Write opinion texts that use specific words that are related to the topic and audience.
Write opinion texts that use linking/transition words and phrases to signal event order.
Write opinion texts that provide evidence of a beginning, middle, and concluding statement or section.
Informative/Explanatory
Write informative/explanatory texts that introduce a topic or text being studied, using complete sentences.
Write informative/explanatory texts that use facts and definitions to develop points in generating paragraphs.
Write informative/explanatory texts that use specific words that are related to the topic and audience.
Write informative/explanatory texts that use linking words and phrases to signal event order.
Write informative/explanatory texts that create a concluding statement or paragraph.
Narrative/Literary
Write fiction or non- fiction narratives and poems that establish a situation/topic based on the studentâ€™s experience or imagination.
Write fiction or non- fiction narratives and poems that introduce a main character and setting.
Write fiction or non- fiction narratives and poems that develop sensory details.
Write fiction or non- fiction narratives and poems that follow a logical sequence of events using complete sentences to create a beginning/middle/end.
Write fiction or non- fiction narratives and poems that use linking/transition words to signal event order.
Write fiction or non- fiction narratives and poems that use specific words that are related to the topic and audience.
Gather, analyze, evaluate, and use information from a variety of sources.
Research Process
Apply research process to generate a list of open-ended questions about topics of interest.
Apply research process to create an individual question about a topic.
Apply research process to use own question to find information on a topic.
Apply research process to gather evidence from available sources, literary and informational.
Apply research process to record basic information from literary and informational texts in simple visual format.
Apply research process to present and evaluate information in written and oral reports or displays, using previously established teacher/student criteria.
Communicate using conventions of English language.
Grammar
In speech and written form, apply standard English grammar to use nouns and pronouns in writing.
In speech and written form, apply standard English grammar to use collective nouns.
In speech and written form, apply standard English grammar to use common irregular nouns.
In speech and written form, apply standard English grammar to use reflexive pronouns.
In speech and written form, apply standard English grammar to use regular verbs.
In speech and written form, apply standard English grammar to use helping verbs with regular verbs.
In speech and written form, apply standard English grammar to use adjectives and adverbs in sentences.
In speech and written form, apply standard English grammar to produce simple declarative, imperative, exclamatory, and interrogative sentences.
Punctuation, Capitalization & Spelling
In written text, write legibly (print, cursive).
In written text, use dialogue that contains quotation marks.
In written text, use apostrophes correctly for contractions.
In written text, capitalize weeks, days, months, holidays.
In written text, capitalize abbreviated titles of people.
In written text, spell words using irregular spelling patterns.
In written text, spell and use the plural of nouns by adding â€“es to nouns ending in -s, -ss, -sh, - ch, or -x.
In written text, use nouns that change their spelling in plural form.
In written text, arrange words in alphabetical order to the second letter.
Listen for a purpose.
Purpose
Develop and apply effective listening skills and strategies in formal and informal settings by following classroom listening rules.
Develop and apply effective listening skills and strategies in formal and informal settings by following three-step instructions, according to classroom expectations.
Listen for entertainment.
Entertainment
Develop and apply effective listening skills and strategies in formal and informal settings by demonstrating active listening, according to classroom expectations.
Speak effectively in collaborative discussions.
Collaborative Discussions
Speak clearly and to the point, using conventions of language when presenting individually or with a group by .
Speak clearly and to the point, using conventions of language when presenting individually or with a group by .
Speak effectively when presenting.
Presenting

Speak clearly, audibly, and to the point, using conventions of language when presenting individually or with a group by explaining a topic (student-chosen or teacher-assigned) while maintaining eye contact with audience.

Speak clearly, audibly, and to the point, using conventions of language when presenting individually or with a group by recalling and telling a story with details, including a beginning, middle, and end.
Speak clearly, audibly, and to the point, using conventions of language when presenting individually or with a group by using academic language and conventions.
